Use: Small fish and shrimps (used in the fish trade; most people say hiki instead)
Copies of a magazine or newspaper, or other packets of papers
Guns, sticks of ink, palanquins, rickshaws, violins
Tools, scissors, saws, trousers, pistols, cakes of tofu, town blocks, servings at a restaurant
Cars, bicycles, machines, mechanical devices, household appliances

Pronunciation: ど do, also たび tabi
Use: Occurrences, number of times, degrees of temperature or angle (see also: kai).
Sequences of letters or drawings that you write or draw without removing your pen off the paper. Not to be confused with "hitsu" (筆) below.

Pronunciation: ふく fuku, ぷく puku
Use: Bowls of matcha (powdered green tea); packets or doses of powdered medicine; puffs (of, e.g., a cigarette); rests or breaks

Pronunciation: ふく fuku, ぷく puku
ふん fun, ぷん pun
がつ gatsu, also つき tsuki
Use: Months of the year. Month-long periods when read tsuki (see also: kagetsu)

Pronunciation: ごん gon, also こと koto

Use: Suits of armour, sets of furniture

Pronunciation: はい hai, ぱい pai, ばい bai
Use: Cups and glasses of drink, spoonfuls, cuttlefish, octopuses, crabs, squid, abalone, boats (slang)

Pronunciation: はつ hatsu, ぱつ patsu
Use: Gunshots, bullets, aerial fireworks; orgasms, sex acts

Pronunciation: ひき hiki, ぴき piki
Use: Small animals, insects, fish, reptiles, amphibians, oni (ogres)

Pronunciation: ひん hin, ぴん pin
Use: Parts of a meal, courses (see also: shina)

Pronunciation: ひつ hitsu, ぴつ pitsu
ほん hon, ぽん pon, ぼん bon
Use: Long, thin objects: rivers, roads, train tracks, ties, pencils, bottles, guitars; also, metaphorically, telephone calls (see also: tsūwa), train or bus routes, movies, home runs, points or bounds, in sports events. Although 本 also means "book", the counter for books is satsu.

Pronunciation: ひょう hyō, ぴょう pyō

Use: Children. As in "father of two (children)", etc.
Tatami mats. The kanji 畳 is also read tatami and is the same one used for the mats. The room size of a washitsu in Japan is given as a number of mats, for example 4½ yo jō han
Articles of law, thin objects, rays or streams of light, streaks of smoke or lightning

Month-long periods (see also: gatsu). 箇 is normally abbreviated using a small katakana ヶ in modern Japanese. Alternatively 個, hiragana か, small katakana ヵ and full-size katakana カ & ケ can also be seen, although only か is similarly frequent.
Occurrences, number of times (see also: do)

Pronunciation: かい kai, がい gai
けん ken, げん gen

Use: Graves, wreaths, CPUs, reactors, elevators, dams

Japanese: 個, 箇, 个, or ヶ
Use: General measure word, used when there is no specific counter. 個 is also used for military units.
Frames, panels. 齣 is virtually unused nowadays.
Groups, a pair of people (twins, a husband and a wife, dancers, etc.)
Board game matches (chess, igo, shogi, mahjong); radio stations, television stations
Thin, flat objects, sheets of paper, photographs, plates, articles of clothing (see also: chaku)

Pronunciation: まき maki or かん kan
Use: Rolls, scrolls, kan for volumes of book
Mirrors, boards for board games (chess, igo, shogi), stages of computer games, walls of a room, tennis courts
Years, school years (grades); not years of age
Days of the month (but see table of exceptions below)
People (but see table of exceptions below)
Food portions (without exceptions, unlike nin above)
Boxes made of folded paper (compare to hako above, which refers to boxes in general)
Bows during worship at a shrine
People, used in the words 一人 (ひとり) and 二人 (ふたり).
Ships, half of a pair (e.g., half of a folding screen), item carried in a bundle (fish, birds, arrows etc.)
Parts of a meal, courses (see also: hin)
used for businesses, i.e. 会社
Sets of things, such as documents or furniture

Pronunciation: しゅるい shurui or しゅ shu

Use: Pairs of footwear, pairs of socks, stockings, tabi
bundles (of banknotes), bunches (of flowers, vegetables), sheaves
Points, dots, pieces of a set
Large animals, cattle, elephants, whales, dolphins, butterflies (頭 means "head")
Time periods, a sixth of either day or night (in the traditional, obsolete way of telling time). See also: jikan
Used as part of the indigenous Japanese numbers 一つ, 二つ, 三つ etc.
Commonly used unit of area equal to 3.3 square metres.

Pronunciation: わ wa, ば ba, ぱ pa
Use: Birds, rabbits* (see note); 羽 means "feather" or "wing."
Stories, episodes of TV series, etc.
Pairs of chopsticks; bowls of rice
